data.text: What Do You Eat When Bikepacking? Is It Practical to Cook on a Tiny Stove?

I have a question about food. My husband and I have always done our bikepacking trips in hotels etc but we‚Äôve decided it‚Äôs time to try camping. üò¨ I‚Äôve seen there are tiny lightweight stoves available but what do people do about evening meals? Is it practical to carry sufficient kit and food and cook on those little stoves? I don‚Äôt want to carry the freeze dried stuff.

I cook rice, lentils and pasta in a tiny stove just fine. On rest days when I have more time I even cook frozen vegetables, potato and other things. Look for a stove that can simmer and get a ceramic pot that's big enough.
data.author: Moinudin Gallotta

data.text: I do rice with foil pouches of curry on top, too. Once the water with rice is boiling, you can take it off the flame, put it in an insulating cozy, and it'll finish cooking that way (with no risk of it burning the rice to the bottom).
data.author: Leif Warner

data.text: Eat big when you pass through a town. üòéüéÇüç∞üéÇüç∞
data.author: Rob Wright

data.text: so I'm looking to go on one of my first trips and I have the same question at the author...I also thought about what you said, eating big, but then how do you ride stuffed to the max after eating big? üòÜ
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text:
U can cook a meal on a little stove u just gotta move it aroujd so it doesnt cook too much in ome spot. I make eggs in a pan on a brs stove only costs like 16 bux on ebay and amazon. https://youtu.be/oRHBG2KqzUs

data.text: Small stove and a pan works a treat
data.author: Sam Walsh

data.author: Sue McIntyre

data.text: jet boil frying pan with fire Marple stove
data.author: Sam Walsh

data.text: I have cooked scratch made chicken Alfredo on backpacking stoves from ingredients I prepped ahead of time. Some things will stay cool carefully packaged and hidden away in your other gear. Some not.
data.author: Ryan Baxter

data.text: You could start off with the freeze dried meal pouches to get used to camp "cooking" and then see what works for you.
data.author: Justin Sher

data.text: Nom nom nom‚Ä¶ small stoves pack a lot of punch - just make sure you get one that has a quality valve allowing a simmer. Some cheap ones (and even expensive) can be more an ‚Äúon/off‚Äù - they‚Äôre more for just water. I do combine the benefits of an MSR 1L pot (water, soups) with a pan-style with lid - I find this very versatile, as it provides a skillet/lid and a shallow saucepan. This alone breaks you out of the ‚Äúonly boil water‚Äù world. I‚Äôve even been able to steam tamales that I bought earlier from a street vendor. Once you know you have a range of preparation methods, your opportunities open up. the perfect condition is where you can get food daily. There really isn‚Äôt anything you can‚Äôt cook. But, if it‚Äôs a couple/few nights, then pack accordingly. There is always rice/pasta, I came across orzo and like that a lot as a base for a lot of things. The simplicity of packets (not cans) of cooked meats (tuna, chicken, pork) are easy to add in. I always like to carry some vegetables that can double for quick-grab munchies or add-in for a stir-fry (snap peas, broccoli, celery are my faves). Farm-fresh eggs don‚Äôt need refrigeration, so another source of protein. Bring a hard cheese - sauces are creamier and EZPZ cheese quesadilla (add chicken!). Gosh - the possibilities are endless.
data.author: Hank Rowe

data.text: thanks that‚Äôs really encouraging, if we start with the right equipment it looks like we can eat very well!
data.author: Sue McIntyre

data.text: you absolutely can. An added thought - before trying something on a whim while in the road, I do now and then when I‚Äôm at the grocery store and done with my shopping, put on my ‚Äútouring cap‚Äù and pretend I‚Äôm shopping for a camp dinner. This is where I‚Äôll experiment‚Ä¶ then go home and cook that for dinner. There‚Äôs also lots of YouTubers out there (that‚Äôs where I picked up the idea of ‚Äústeaming‚Äù). Bon Appetit!
data.author: Hank Rowe

data.text:
I use one of these pans and my stove, fuel and fire starting kit fit inside. Not for gram counters though. I burn wood or alcohol in a trangia burner. This set up is not allowed in some areas. Be sure of stove restrictions where you plan to go. Many areas require the stove to have an on - off valve. I can cook about anything that fits in my pan. https://frybake.com/
Fry-Bake Pans for Outdoor Cooking: Frying and Baking
frybake.com
data.author: Douglas Miner

data.text: Dehydrate and vacuum your own food, saves weight, space, tastes great (assuming you can cook) and you know exactly what's in it. Also the you can use these tiny stoves as you are only boiling water to rehydrate and heat up.
data.author: Beine√°n √ì hEid√≠n

data.text: Those freeze dried pouches are actually pretty good to start with. Especially while you are learning. There are tons of books out there for cooking while backpacking. Tons of options.
data.author: Don Martin

data.text: Here's a list of good list of fast cooking/lightweight food, boil in bag rice, quinoa, cous cous, knorr pasta packets, instant mashed potatoes, etc. You can then combine these bases with dried refried beans, canned fish/chicken, lentils, etc. Lastly bring a small bottle of olive oil or similar to add fat into your meal.
data.author: Steven Baker

data.text: I personally don't use a stove since I'm insulin resistant type 2 diabetic and all those carbs are not good for me. I know from my hiking days you can "cold soak" food in the morning and with a little heat, it's ready to eat for dinner.
data.author: Brandi Jackson Hodges

data.text: If your in bear country make sure to hang your stove with your food. A bear bit clear through mine! The freeze dried meals are great or you could bring a small ice pack with chicken and make tin foil fajitas in the fire for day one.
data.author: Karen Kersch Tone

data.text: yikes! I‚Äôm in the UK so no bears to worry about luckily!
data.author: Sue McIntyre

data.text: Tbh I think stoves are over rated. I just carry and eat cold food. Bean burritos, or things I can get from a grocery store.
data.author: Andy Hatch

data.text: You can make pretty well anything you‚Äôd cook on your stove top at home, but it really depends on how much you want to carry & what food will keep. Friends I‚Äôd mine say some of the commercial freeze meals are quite good, but they are too high in carbs for me, so I dehydrate a lot of my camp food. That makes it lighter & more compact to pack. Stoves like the MSR pocket rocket are good both for simmering & for boiling. If I‚Äôm doing a light trip, I take one pot that‚Äôs big enough to cook a meal for 2 people, though I‚Äôll Occasionally take 2 nesting pots if needed for some meals. I don‚Äôt take any canned food, as it‚Äôs too heavy, but there are packets of tuna & packets of ethnic foods that make a good base for meals.
data.author: Cheryl Leskiw

data.text: If you can have a fire, cook in it.
data.author: Bob Bergen

data.text: I put 4 rocks in before I lit the fire
data.author: Bob Bergen

data.text: Where are you going? In France and some parts of Spain (probably other places too, but these are places I‚Äôve done it), it‚Äôs quite possible to camp and eat out. Not so much in BC where I live because campgrounds are never close to services (and never have restaurants). I‚Äôve only camped in campgrounds when cycle touring because I like having a shower after a day of riding (another thing that isn‚Äôt always possible in BC).
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: Likely France, Spain and UK but we may need to wild camp in remote areas.
data.author: Sue McIntyre

data.text: if camping is only a possibility, perhaps a small stove and freeze-dried meals are the way to go. If you want to actually cook, not just boil water, those stoves (and pots and other utensils) add up to a fair bit of weight and bulk.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: I use a tiny backpacking burner to boil water. Allows for making those MRE meals or oatmeal and coffee in the morning. Something that burns isobutane.
data.author: Lisa Andresky

data.text:
Check out https://montyboca.com/ Delightful meals that are not freeze dried
Monty Boca: Trail-tested Recipes & Backpacking Meals
montyboca.com
data.author: Tracy Irvin

data.text: Depends on the weather condition. Wood stove is economical. Bring cans food and instant noodle as for myself.
data.author: Steven Leong Siu Weng

data.text: I might recommend the MSR whisper lite white gas stove. It packs down pretty small and you can generally do more with it including cook with a small skillet.
data.author: Andrew Heindl

data.author: Andrew Heindl

data.text: FWIW I usually only cook breakfast and one or two dinners. I have a hard time packing enough calories with me so I often rely on restaurant/grocery store/gas station takeout along the way (get 1-3 meals to-go). So far I haven't toured through any super remote areas though.
data.author: Adam Pagenkopf
